Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer screen, feeling the familiar knot of anxiety tighten in my stomach. In ten minutes, our weekly team meeting would start—a routine catch-up, nothing urgent, and I knew it would be recorded for anyone who couldn’t make it. Still, I could already imagine the disappointed look on my manager’s face if I didn’t show up, the subtle implication that I wasn’t a team player. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the community center started in fifteen minutes. I’d promised to be there on time, but I also knew that the first half hour was always slow, and there were plenty of other volunteers who could cover until I arrived. Yet, I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was letting someone down, no matter what I chose. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me—my colleagues expecting my presence and participation, the volunteer coordinator counting on my reliability. I sat frozen at my desk, torn between two worlds, wishing I could be in both places at once.
